*Today’s Verses:*

*Jesus traveled through all the cities and villages of that **area,
teaching in the synagogues and announcing the **Good *

*News** about the Kingdom. And wherever He **went, He healed the people of
every sort of disease **and illness. He felt great pity for the crowds
that **came, because their problems were so great and **they *

*didn’t know where to go for help. *(Mt. 9:35-37)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus was and is moved by the condition of the people’s lives. He came to
be the Shepherd the one who could show people

how to avoid life’s pitfalls (see Jn. 10:14). Jesus looked at the crowds
following Him and referred them as a field ripe for

harvest. Many people are ready to give their lives to Christ if someone
would show them how. Jesus commands us to

pray that people will respond to this need for workers. Often, when we pray
for something God answers our prayers by

using us. *Be prepared for God* *to use you to show another person the way
to Him.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus was and is moved by the condition of the people’s lives. He came to be the Shepherd the one who could show people
how to avoid life’s pitfalls (see John 10:14). Jesus looked at the crowds following Him and referred them as a field ripe for harvest. Many people are ready to give their lives to Christ if someone would show them how. Jesus commands us to
pray that people will respond to this need for workers. Often, when we pray for something God answers our prayers by
using us. Be prepared for God to use you to show another person the way to Him.
original_verse_text: Jesus traveled through all the cities and villages of that area, teaching in the synagogues and announcing the Good  News about the Kingdom. And wherever He went, He healed the people of every sort of disease and illness. He felt great pity for the crowds that came, because their problems were so great and they  didn’t know where to go for help.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, for You have sent Your Son, the Good Shepherd, to guide us and lead us to eternal life. Lord, we see the crowds, longing for Your love and truth, and we are moved by the vast harvest that awaits. Stir in us a deep compassion, that we may heed Your call to pray for more workers to tend to Your flock. Use us, Lord, as instruments of Your grace, that we may be bold in sharing the gospel and leading others to the path of salvation. In Your name, we pray. Amen.
reflection: Jesus was and is moved by the condition of the people's lives. He came to be the Shepherd, the one who could show people how to avoid life's pitfalls (see John 10:14). Jesus looked at the crowds following Him and referred to them as a field ripe for harvest. Many people are ready to give their lives to Christ if someone would show them how. Jesus commands us to pray that people will respond to this need for workers. Often, when we pray for something, God answers our prayers by using us. Be prepared for God to use you to show another person the way to Him.
subject: Jesus's Compassion

And wherever He went, He healed the people of every sort of disease and illness. He felt great pity for the crowds that came, because their problems were so great and they  didn’t know where to go for help.

subject   : Subject:LOVE BEYOND HUMAN UNDERSTANDING (4-3-2020)

*Today’s Verses:*

*I pray that Christ will be more and more *

*at home in your hearts **as you trust in Him. May your roots go down deep
into the soil*

*of God’s marvelous love. And may you*

*have the power to under**stand, as all God’s people should, how wide, how
long, how*

*high, and how deep His love really is. May you experience **the love of
Christ, **though *

*it is so great you will never fully **under-*

*stand **it. Then you will be filled with the fullness of **life and power
that comes from God. *(Eph. 4:17-19)



*Today’s Reflection:*

This “fullness” is fully expressed in Christ (Col 2:9-10), in union with
Christ and through His empowering Spirit, we are

complete. We have all the fullness of God available to us. But we must
appropriate that fullness through faith and through prayer as we daily live
for Him, Paul’s

prayer for the Ephesians, and also for us.

is *let us ask the Holy Spirit to fill every aspect of our **life to the
fullest.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
This “fullness” is fully expressed in Christ (Colossians 2:9-10), in union with Christ and through His empowering Spirit, we are complete. We have all the fullness of God available to us. But we must appropriate that fullness through faith and through prayer as we daily live for Him, Paul’s prayer for the Ephesians, and also for us.
is let us ask the Holy Spirit to fill every aspect of our life to the fullest.

And may you have the power to understand, as all God’s people should, how wide, how long, how high, and how deep His love really is. May you experience the love of Christ, though  it is so great you will never fully under-  stand it. Then you will be filled with the fullness of life and power that comes from God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging that in Christ we have the fullness of Your divine nature (Colossians 2:9-10). Lord, we desire to walk in this fullness, to be complete and empowered by Your Spirit. Fill us, we pray, that we may no longer live in the futility of our minds, but be transformed by the renewing of our hearts (Ephesians 4:17-19). May we daily appropriate the abundance of Your grace and live for Your glory. Amen.
reflection: This “fullness” is fully expressed in Christ (Colossians 2:9-10). In union with Christ and through His empowering Spirit, we are complete. We have all the fullness of God available to us. But we must appropriate that fullness through faith and through prayer as we daily live for Him. Paul's prayer for the Ephesians, and also for us, is let us ask the Holy Spirit to fill every aspect of our life to the fullest.

subject   : Subject: GENTLE BUT PERSISTENT (4-4-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verse:*

*Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper **time we will
reap a harvest if we do not give up. *(Gal. 6:9)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Yes, I agree it can be discouraging to continue to do the right thing and
receive no word of thanks or see no tangible

results. But our efforts to influence people to love God, accept Christ as
Savior, and live under the direction of the Holy Spirit

should be gentle as the tapping of a cork ball, *BUT, we should **also be
persistent and faithful—may we be so.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Yes, I agree it can be discouraging to continue to do the right thing and receive no word of thanks or see no tangible
results.
But our efforts to influence people to love God, accept Christ as Savior, and live under the direction of the Holy Spirit
should be gentle as the tapping of a cork ball, BUT, we should also be persistent and faithful—may we be so.
original_verse_text: Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, seeking the strength and perseverance to continue in the good works You have called us to do. When the path seems long and the rewards elusive, help us to remain steadfast, knowing that our labor in the Lord is never in vain. Grant us the gentle wisdom to influence others towards Your love and the unwavering faith to be persistent in our efforts. May we be faithful servants, tapping gently but persistently, until Your will is accomplished. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Yes, I agree it can be discouraging to continue to do the right thing and receive no word of thanks or see no tangible results. But our efforts to influence people to love God, accept Christ as Savior, and live under the direction of the Holy Spirit should be gentle as the tapping of a cork ball, BUT, we should also be persistent and faithful—may we be so.
subject: Gentle but Persistent
verse_text: Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up.

message_id: 1714750b9a2d18cd
subject   : Subject: STEADFAST IN VIEW OF SUFFERING (4-5-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Sat, 4 Apr 2020 17:30:05 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verses:*

*As the time drew near for His return to heaven, Jesus resolutely **set out
for Jerusalem. Jesus sent messengers ahead *

*to a Samaritan village to prepare for His arrival. But they were turned
away. The people of the village refused to have any-thing to do with Jesus
because He had resolved to go to Jerusalem. *

(Lk. 9:51-53)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Even though Jesus knew He would face persecution and death in Jerusalem, He
was determined to go there. Christ’s love for us compelled Him to go there.
That kind of resolve should characterize *our* life too. When God gives us
a course of action, we must move steadily toward our destination, no matter
what potential hazards await us there. *Let us stretch ourselves to do
something that requires a sacrifice.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text: Even though Jesus knew He would face persecution and death in Jerusalem, He was determined to go there. Christ’s love for us compelled Him to go there. That kind of resolve should characterize our life too. When God gives us a course of action, we must move steadily toward our destination, no matter what potential hazards await us there. Let us stretch ourselves to do something that requires a sacrifice.
original_verse_text: As the time drew near for His return to heaven, Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem. Jesus sent messengers ahead  to a Samaritan village to prepare for His arrival. But they were turned away. The people of the village refused to have anything to do with Jesus because He had resolved to go to Jerusalem.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, seeking to follow in the footsteps of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Just as He was resolute in His journey to Jerusalem, may we too have the courage and determination to walk the path You have set before us, even when it requires sacrifice and perseverance. Grant us the strength to stretch ourselves, to do what is difficult, and to remain steadfast in our commitment to You. May our love for You and for others compel us to move forward, no matter the challenges that may arise. We trust in Your guiding hand and pray that Your will be done in our lives. Amen.
reflection: Even though Jesus knew He would face persecution and death in Jerusalem, He was determined to go there. Christ's love for us compelled Him to go there. That kind of resolve should characterize our life too. When God gives us a course of action, we must move steadily toward our destination, no matter what potential hazards await us there. Let us stretch ourselves to do something that requires a sacrifice.

But they were turned away. The people of the village refused to have anything to do with Jesus because He had resolved to go to Jerusalem.

subject   : Subject: HIS PROMISE WITH CONFIDENCE (4-6-2020)

*Today’s Verse’s:*

*And so, dear brothers and sisters, we can boldly heaven’s **Most Holy
Place because of the blood of Jesus. By his **death Jesus opened a new and
life-giving way through*

*the curtain into the most Holy Place. *

(Heb. 10:19-20)



*Today’s Reflection:*

God finds great pleasure in our desire to talk with Him. He’s never to busy,
and He’ll never turn us away. We can enter

His presence anytime, confident that He

welcomes us, *thanks to what Jesus did on the cross.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
God finds great pleasure in our desire to talk with Him. He’s never to busy, and He’ll never turn us away. We can enter His presence anytime, confident that He
welcomes us, thanks to what Jesus did on the cross.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, rejoicing in the confidence we have to enter Your presence through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Thank You for the bold access You have granted us, that we may approach Your throne with assurance and find grace to help in our time of need. May our prayers be a sweet fragrance to You, as we draw near to You with reverence and awe. Amen.

subject   : Subject: LIVING DURING DIFFICULT TIMES (4-7-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Mon, 6 Apr 2020 17:39:16 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*“Sanctify yourselves against tomorrow” *(Num. 11:18)



*Today’s Reflection:*

*It’ all about attitude**—*Someone once said, my past is gone; my presence
is passing; my future is arriving.” The best thing about the future is that
in comes in

degrees, a day at a time. We can manage that! Whatever it holds, our future
is ours.

If it be fair weather, let us bask in the sun; if it be stormy, let bend with
the wind. The future belongs to those who can make adjustments. *Keep your
mind on** God, *

*and receive His promise of perfect peace.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
It’ all about attitude— Someone once said, my past is gone; my presence is passing; my future is arriving.” The best thing about the future is that in comes in
degrees, a day at a time. We can manage that! Whatever it holds, our future is ours. If it be fair weather, let us bask in the sun; if it be stormy, let bend with the wind. The future belongs to those who can make adjustments. Keep your mind on God, and receive His promise of perfect peace.
original_verse_text: "Sanctify yourselves against tomorrow"
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that our future is in Your hands. As we face the uncertainties that lie ahead, we cling to Your promise of perfect peace found in Isaiah 26:3. Help us to keep our minds steadfast on You, trusting that You will guide us through each day, whether fair or stormy. Grant us the wisdom and strength to make the necessary adjustments, knowing that our past is gone and our future is arriving. May we bask in the warmth of Your presence and bend with the wind of Your will. We thank You, Lord, for the gift of each new day. Amen.
reflection: It's all about attitude. Someone once said, “My past is gone; my present is passing; my future is arriving.” The best thing about the future is that it comes in degrees, a day at a time. We can manage that! Whatever it holds, our future is ours. If it be fair weather, let us bask in the sun; if it be stormy, let us bend with the wind. The future belongs to those who can make adjustments. Keep your mind on God, and receive His promise of perfect peace.
subject: Living During Difficult Times
verse_text: “Sanctify yourselves against tomorrow”

subject   : Subject: THE FATHER'S GIFT (4-8-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*But then God our Savior, showed us His kindness and Love. **He saved us,
not because of the good things we did, but*

*because of His mercy. He washed away our sins and gave **us new life
through the Holy Spirit. *(Titus 3:4-6)



*Today’s Reflection:*

All three persons of the trinity are mentioned in these verses, because all
three participate in the work of salvation.

Based upon the redemptive work of His

Son, the Father forgives us and sends His Holy Spirit to wash away our sins
and continually renews us.

*The Holy Spirit, continually renews our hearts. *

* Pastor Sather *
original_reflection_text:
All three persons of the trinity are mentioned in these verses, because all three participate in the work of salvation. Based upon the redemptive work of His
Son, the Father forgives us and sends His Holy Spirit to wash away our sins and continually renews us. The Holy Spirit, continually renews our hearts.
original_verse_text: But then God our Savior, showed us His kindness and Love. He saved us, not because of the good things we did, but because of His mercy. He washed away our sins and gave us new life through the Holy Spirit.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we praise You for the boundless love and mercy You have shown us through Your Son, Jesus Christ. We give thanks that by Your grace, we have been saved and made alive in Him. Lord, we humbly ask that Your Holy Spirit would continually renew our hearts, washing away our sins and transforming us to be more like Christ. May we live as Your beloved children, filled with gratitude and a desire to serve You. Amen.
reflection: All three persons of the Trinity are mentioned in these verses, because all three participate in the work of salvation. Based upon the redemptive work of His Son, the Father forgives us and sends His Holy Spirit to wash away our sins and continually renews us. The Holy Spirit continually renews our hearts.
subject: The Father's Gift

subject   : Subject: JESUS, THE ONLY WAY (4-9-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 8 Apr 2020 18:09:33 -0500
===================================================================

*Today’s Verse’s:*

*Let not your heart be troubled. You trust God, now trust in me. **There
are many rooms in my Father’s home, and I am going **to prepare a place for
you. If this were not so I would have **told you. *

(14-1-3)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Apart from what Jesus has done, the thought of aging and dying would be

over whelming. Jesus’ words show that the way to eternal life is
secure—that is as secure as your trust in Jesus. He has already prepared
the way to eternal life. The only issue that may still be unsettled is your
willingness to believe. Jesus

has promise it to all who believe in Him. Although the details of eternity
are unknown, *we need not fear because Jesus is **preparing for us and will
spend eternity with us. *

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Apart from what Jesus has done, the thought of aging and dying would be over whelming. Jesus’ words show that the way to eternal life is secure—that is as secure as your trust in Jesus. He has already prepared the way to eternal life. The only issue that may still be unsettled is your willingness to believe. Jesus
has promise it to all who believe in Him. Although the details of eternity are unknown, we need not fear because Jesus is preparing for us and will spend eternity with us.
original_verse_text: Let not your heart be troubled. You trust God, now trust in me. There are many rooms in my Father’s home, and I am going to prepare a place for you. If this were not so I would have told you.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come to You with grateful hearts, knowing that apart from Your Son, Jesus, the way to eternal life would be uncertain and overwhelming. We thank You that Jesus has secured the path to everlasting life, and that all who believe in Him will dwell with You forever. Help us to trust fully in Your Son, the Way, the Truth, and the Life, as we anticipate the glorious eternity You have prepared for us. In Jesus' name we pray, Amen.
reflection: Apart from what Jesus has done, the thought of aging and dying would be overwhelming. Jesus' words show that the way to eternal life is secure—that is as secure as your trust in Jesus. He has already prepared the way to eternal life. The only issue that may still be unsettled is your willingness to believe. Jesus has promised it to all who believe in Him. Although the details of eternity are unknown, we need not fear because Jesus is preparing for us and will spend eternity with us.

original_content:
message_id: 1716150c2a6387cd
subject   : Subject: VICTORY IN CHRIST (4-10-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Thu, 9 Apr 2020 18:40:15 -0500
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):
===================================================================
*Today’s Verse:*

*At about three o’clock, Jesus called out with a loud **voice, “Eli, Eli,
lema sabachthani?” which means,**“My God, my God, why have you forsaken
me?”*

(Mt. 27:46)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus was not questioning God; He was quoting the first line of Ps. 22—a
deep expression of the anguish He felt when He took on the sins of the
whole world.

Which caused Him to be separated from His Father. This is what Jesus
dreaded as He prayed to God in the garden to take the cup from Him Mt.
26:39. The

physical agony was horrible, but even worse was the period of spiritual
separation from God. *Jesus **suffered this double death so that we would
never*

*have to experience eternal separation from God.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
Jesus was not questioning God; He was quoting the first line of Psalm 22—a deep expression of the anguish He felt when He took on the sins of the whole world. Which caused Him to be separated from His Father. This is what Jesus dreaded as He prayed to God in the garden to take the cup from Him Matthew 26:39. The
physical agony was horrible, but even worse was the period of spiritual separation from God. Jesus suffered this double death so that we would never have to experience eternal separation from God.
original_verse_text: At about three o’clock, Jesus called out with a loud voice, "Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?” which means,“My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?"
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts full of gratitude for the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. In the depths of His anguish, He cried out, feeling the weight of our sin and the separation from You. Yet, through His suffering, we have been reconciled and given the promise of eternal life with You. Lord, help us to never take for granted the price that was paid for our salvation. May we cling to the truth that You are ever-present, even in our darkest moments. We praise You, our faithful God. Amen.
reflection: Jesus was not questioning God; He was quoting the first line of Psalm 22—a deep expression of the anguish He felt when He took on the sins of the whole world. This caused Him to be separated from His Father. This is what Jesus dreaded as He prayed to God in the garden to take the cup from Him (Matthew 26:39). The physical agony was horrible, but even worse was the period of spiritual separation from God. Jesus suffered this double death so that we would never have to experience eternal separation from God.
subject: Victory in Christ
verse_text: At about three o’clock, Jesus called out with a loud voice, “Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?” which means,“My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”

*Today's Verses:*
*Our own sinful selves were crucified with Christ so*
*that sin might lose its power in our lives. We are no*
*longer slaves to sin. for when we died with Christ we*
*were set free from the power of sin *(Ro. 6:6-7)

*Today's Reflection:*
Our sinful nature, died once and for all, so we are
freed from it's power. The "power of sin" refers to
our rebellious sin-loving nature inherited from
Adam. Though we often willingly cooperate with
our sinful nature, it is not us but the sin in us that
is evil. And it is this power of sin at work in our
life that is defeated. Paul has already stated that through faith in Christ
we stand acquitted, "not
guilty" before God. *Because of this we dare to*
*live freely, impowered by the blood.*
* Pastor Sather*

*Subject: EASTER MORROW STILLS OUR SORROW *(4-12-2020)



*Today’s Verses:*

*So they went in, but they could not find the body of the Lord **Jesus. . .
. Then the men asked, “Why are you looking in a** tomb for **someone who is
alive. He isn’t here! He has risen **from the dead!”*

(Lk. 24:3, 5-6)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The resurrection validated a promise Jesus made: *“I am the **resurrection
and the life. Anyone who believes in me will **live, even after dying. *(Jn.
11:25) NLT. Jesus emerged the victor; and we are victors too. Not just over
physical death someday, but over the

enemy’s attempts to defeat us now. the enemy wants nothing more than to
destroy us and seal us in an emotional, mental, or spiritual tomb. Alone
Afraid. Helpless.

Dead to joy, peace, purpose, and passion. Dead to God’s purpose for us and
to all things related to His Kingdom. Jesus said,

give them a rich and satisfying **life” *(Jn. 10:12) NLT. *His
resurrection confirmed this truth. **He *

*burst* *from the grave fully alive and victorious. Let’s* *follow in His
steps.*

* Pastor Sather *

*Today's Reflection:*

*How do I know that Christ has risen?*

*What proof have I to give?*

*He touched my life one blessed day,*

*And I began to live.*



* How do I know He left the tomb*

*That morning long ago ?*

*I met him just this morning, *

*And my heart is still aglow.*



*How do I know that endless life*

*He gained for me that day?*

*His life within is proof enough*

*Of immortality. *



*How do I know that Christ still lives,*

*Rich blessing to impart?*

*He walks with me along the way*

*And lives within my heart.*

* Pastor Sather *

* (P.S.)*

*(*Let us not forget all Jesus did for us)

subject   : Subject: A LIMIT TO HUMAN UNDERSTANDING (4-14-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verses:*

*Jesus said. . . “Mary!” She turned *

*and said to Him **in Hebrew,“Rabboni!”*

* (which means (Teacher). **Jesus said to *

*her, Stop clinging to me for I have **not *

*yet ascended to the Father. *

(Jn. 20:16-17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Can you imagine what it would have

been like to be Mary on that day? Her

world ended with Jesus’ death. He was her teacher, but much more, Jesus

loved her not only for what she was,

but who she wanted to be. The world

looks at the outside—God sees the heart.

I believe Jesus saw her desperation, how

lost she was without Him. And though

He felt compassion, He wanted her to

move on from that place. From now on she needed to learn to walk in
communion with the Holy Spirit. *Are there aspects *

*of your faith **you need to release in order to move onward **and upward *

*with Jesus?*

* Pastor Sather *

He was her teacher, but much more, Jesus
loved her not only for what she was, but who she wanted to be. The world looks at the outside—God sees the heart. I believe Jesus saw her desperation, how lost she was without Him. And though He felt compassion, He wanted her to move on from that place. From now on she needed to learn to walk in communion with the Holy Spirit. Are there aspects of your faith you need to release in order to move onward and upward with Jesus?

Like Mary, we have experienced the pain of loss and the longing for Your presence. Yet, in Your infinite wisdom, You call us to move forward, to walk in communion with the Holy Spirit. Help us to release the aspects of our faith that hold us back, that we may press onward and upward, ever growing in our relationship with You. May we see with the eyes of our heart, and find comfort in the knowledge that You see us, not for what we are, but for who we can become in You. We trust in Your perfect plan, and pray that Your Spirit would guide us, even as we navigate the uncertainties of this life. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*And all who believe in God’s Son have life. To those who **don’t believe
the Son will never experience eternal life, **but the *

*wrath of God remains upon them. *(Jn.3:36)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus says that those who believe in Him *have (*not *will *have) eternal
life. John, the author of this Gospel, has been demon-strating that Jesus
is the true Son of God.

Jesus sets before us the greatest choice in life. We are responsible to
decide for

ourselves whom we will obey. (Jos. 24:15), and God wants us to choose Him

and live (Deut. 30:15-20). The wrath of God is God’s final Judgement and
rejection of the sinners. To put

off the choice is to choose not to follow Christ. The *great divide* comes
down to

choosing Christ and receiving eternal life *or *not believe and
receive the wrath
of God. *Indecision is a fatal decision,*

*especially at a time* *when none of us know if we **will be one of the
next statistics.*

* Pastor Sather*

*(On which side of the divide are you standing)*

May our lives reflect our commitment to You, that we may not be found among the indecisive, but firmly rooted in our faith in Christ. We pray this in the name of Jesus, our Savior. Amen.

*But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, **kindness,
goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-**control, *

*against such things there is no law.*

(Gal. 5:22-23)



*Today’s Reflection;*

The fruit of the Spirit is the spontaneous work of the Holy Spirit in us. The
Spirit

produces these character traits that are

found in-the-nature-of-Christ. They are

the by-product of Christ’s control—we can’t obtain them by trying to gain
them

without His help. If we want the fruit of the Spirit to grow in us, we
must join
our

life to His (Jn. 15: 4, 5). We must know

Him, love Him, remember Him, and imitate Him. As a result, we will fulfill

the intended purpose of The law—to

love God and our neighbors. *Which **of *

*these qualities do you want the Spirit to*

*produce in you?*

* Pastor Sather *

Lord, help us to abide in Christ, that we may bear much fruit for Your glory. May Your Spirit work mightily within us, transforming us into the likeness of Christ. We surrender ourselves to You, that Your will may be done in us. Amen.

*Today’s Verses:*

*At this time, many of His disciples turned away and **and deserted Him.
Then Jesus turned to the Twelve **and asked, “Are you going to leave,
too?” *(Jn. 6-66-67)

*Today’s Reflection:*

These have to be some of the saddest words in the Scripture: “Many of His
disciples turned back and no longer followed Him” (Jn. 6:66). *I wonder how*

*they felt on Good Friday*, *on Resurrection Sunday*, *or the day they
stood before Him*, at the end of their lives. The hymn that comes to my
mind is*: I have **decided to follow Jesus. No turning back. No turning*

*back.* Many people look everywhere for eternal life and miss Christ, the
only source.”* In these days we **need to stay with Him, especially when
there is so*

*much confusion as to what the future holds.*

* Pastor Sather *

Help us to cling to You, the source of eternal life, and never to turn back, no matter the circumstances. Grant us the strength to persevere in our faith, even in the face of confusion and uncertainty. We ask this in the name of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

message_id: 1718ab70b21dda34
subject   : Subject: HIS IDENTITY REVEALED (4-18-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

date      : Fri, 17 Apr 2020 19:36:24 -0500

*Today’s Verses:*

*When He was at the table with them, He took bread, **gave thanks, broke it
and began to give it to them. **Then their eyes were opened and they
recognized **Him, *

*and He disappeared from their sight.*

(Lk. 24:30-31)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Just after Jesus’s Triumph over death, Cleopas and another disciple
traveled the road to Emmaus, discussing our Lord and His empty tomb. As
they walked, Christ

joined them, but they did not recognize Him. After reaching the village,
they invited Him to join them at the table,

and He accepted. As Jesus *gave thanks *and broke the bread with them,
their eyes were opened, and they saw Him for who He truly was. As Jesus gave
thanks, what did He say that revealed His true

identity to the apostles? I wonder,

because after they recognized Him He

disappeared. Had He told them all they needed to hear and cut the meeting
short.

I‘m sure His prayer would forever remain

embedded in their minds. *Let us*

*remember** to **ask our Lord to always supply the right things **to say so
friends will welcome Him into our visit.*

*Pastor Sather*

identity to the apostles? I wonder, because after they recognized Him He disappeared. Had He told them all they needed to hear and cut the meeting short. I‘m sure His prayer would forever remain
embedded in their minds. Let us remember to ask our Lord to always supply the right things to say so friends will welcome Him into our visit.

Lord, may we too have our eyes opened to see Your presence with us, and may our words and actions reveal the truth of Your identity to those around us. Guide us to speak the words that will welcome You into our lives and homes. Amen.

subject   : Subject ALONE WITH THE FATHER (4-19-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

date      : Sat, 18 Apr 2020 18:14:35 -0500

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness to pray*. (Lk. 5:16)



*Today’s Reflection:*

People were flocking to hear Jesus preach and to have their diseases
healed, but Jesus often withdrew to a quiet solitary place to pray. I don’t
think anyone would disagree with me when I say: *many things* clamor for
our attention, and we often

run ourselves ragged attending to them. Like Jesus, however, we should take
time to withdraw to a quiet and deserted place

to pray. Our strength comes from God, *and we can only be **strengthened by
spending time with Him. *

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
People were flocking to hear Jesus preach and to have their diseases healed, but Jesus often withdrew to a quiet solitary place to pray. I don’t think anyone would disagree with me when I say: many things clamor for our attention, and we often
run ourselves ragged attending to them. Like Jesus, however, we should take time to withdraw to a quiet and deserted place
to pray. Our strength comes from God, and we can only be strengthened by spending time with Him.
original_verse_text: Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness to pray.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before you, seeking the quiet solitude that you so often modeled for us. Amidst the clamor of the world and the demands on our time, we long to withdraw and be alone with you, to be strengthened by your presence and to find our rest in you. Grant us the discipline to make time for prayer, that we may be renewed and empowered to serve you faithfully. In your Son's name, we pray. Amen.
reflection: People were flocking to hear Jesus preach and to have their diseases healed, but Jesus often withdrew to a quiet, solitary place to pray. I don't think anyone would disagree with me when I say: many things clamor for our attention, and we often run ourselves ragged attending to them. Like Jesus, however, we should take time to withdraw to a quiet and deserted place to pray. Our strength comes from God, and we can only be strengthened by spending time with Him.
subject: Alone with the Father
verse_text: Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness to pray.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Thereafter, Hagar used another name to refer to the Lord, **who had spoken
to her, she said, “You are the God who sees **me.” She also said,“Have I
truly seen the One*

*who sees me?” *(Gen. 16:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

We have become a more transient society do to the job market. Also, studies
reveal that many people substitute social media

for real-life personal interaction. A person who had been moving around the
country as an empty nester said, he was made aware of the power of a smile
and a friendly greeting to ease loneliness. He said it has also taught me
to find com-

fort in knowing that even when people ignore me, Jesus loves me so much
that His eyes never leave me.

*None of us like to feel invisible.*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verse:*

receive such grace—unearned and undeserved

favor—only because of Jesus Christ. Yes,

we are saved by Him for eternity, but we are also sustained by Him daily. *And
believe me, Jesus also will **surprise *

*us with His lavish gifts.*

* Pastor Sather *

in God, for I will yet **Praise Him, my Savior and my God. *(Ps. 42:5)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus looked at people and knew exactly what they needed. He confronted the
Pharisees' hypocrisy (Mt. 23). He knew the woman who touched His robe
needed a personal encounter besides physical

healing (Lk. 8:43-48). Jesus wants to pinpoint the cause of our painful

symptoms and show us the cure. *He is waiting for us to consult Him.*

* Pastor Sather*

*Today’s Verses:*

*So Christ Himself gave the apostles, the prophets, the evangelists, the
pastors and teachers. Their responsibility **is to equip God’s people
for works of service, so the*

*body of Christ may be built up until we all reach unity **in the faith and
in the knowledge of the Son of God and*

*become mature, attaining to the whole measure of His** fullness of
Christ. *

(Eph. 4:11-13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Our oneness in Christ does not destroy our individuality. The Holy Spirit
has given each Christian special gifts for

building up the church. Now that we

have these gifts, it is crucial to use them. Are you spiritually mature,
exercising the gifts God, that He has given you? If you know what your
gifts are, look for opportunities to serve. If you do not know, ask God to
show you, perhaps with

the help of your minister or Christian friends you will recognize, *your
special area of service, use your **gifts to strengthen and encourage the
church.*

* Pastor Sather*

Help us to recognize and faithfully steward the unique abilities You have entrusted to each of us, that we may use them to build up the body of Christ and bring glory to Your name. Grant us spiritual maturity to discern our callings and serve one another in love, that Your church may be strengthened and encouraged. In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*I and the Father are one. *(Jn. 10:30)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The Bible says that God is love (I Jn. 4:8). It also tells us that Jesus
and His Father are one, which means Jesus is love. We are told to abide in,
dwell in Him, which means immersing ourselves in that vast pool of love
until it can be said of us:

*The good news is that the goal won’t come **in striving, but in diving in
and becoming.*

* Pastor Sather*

(4-29-20)

*Today’s Verse’s*

*Don’t worry about having enough food or drink or clothing. **Why be like
the pagans who are so deeply concerned about **these *

*things? Your heavenly Father already knows all your **needs, and He will
give you all you need from day to day **if** you *

*live for Him and make the Kingdom of God your **primary concern. *(Mt.
6:31-33)


*Today’s Reflection:*

To “make the Kingdom of God your primary concern” means to put God first in
your life, to fill your thoughts with His desires, to take His character
for your pattern, and to serve Him in everything. *What is really
important **to you?* People-- objects--goals--and other desires all

compete for priority. Any of these can quickly bump God out of first place
*if*

*you don’t actively choose to **give Him first place in every area of your
life. *

* Pastor Sather*

original_verse_text: The Lord will rescue me from every evil attack and will bring me safely to His heavenly kingdom. To Him be glory for ever and ever, Amen.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging the many fears and anxieties that so often cloud our days. Help us to remember the truth of Your Word, that You are our deliverer, that You hear our cries, and that You shine Your light upon us. May we find our refuge in You, the only safe place for our souls. Give us the courage to hand over our fears, trusting in Your perfect love and unfailing grace. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: I believe we often allow our days to be overshadowed by fears large and small, real and perceived, and that is exactly what the enemy wants—to steal our peace, grace, love, and joy. Or we can hand our fears and ourselves over to the only Safe Place, Jesus.
subject: What is Overshadowing Your Life?
verse_text: The Lord will rescue me from every evil attack and will bring me safely to His heavenly kingdom. To Him be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord your God is the God of all gods and Lord of **all lords. He is
the Great*

*God, **mighty and awesome, **who shows no partially and takes no bribes. *

(Deut. 10:17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

In saying that the Lord your God is God of all gods and Lord of lords,
Moses was distinguishing the true God from all the local gods worshiped
throughout the land.

Then Moses went a step further, calling God “mighty and awesome.” He has
such awesome power and justice that people cannot stand before Him without
His mercy. Fortunately, His mercy toward His people is unlimited. When we
began to

grasp the extent of His mercy toward us we see what true love is and how
deeply God loves us. *Although our sins deserve* *severe judgment, **God
has chosen to show love* *and mercy to all **who seek Him.*

* Pastor Sather*
original_reflection_text:
In saying that the Lord your God is God of all gods and Lord of lords, Moses was distinguishing the true God from all the local gods worshiped throughout the land.
Then Moses went a step further, calling God “mighty and awesome.” He has such awesome power and justice that people cannot stand before Him without His mercy. Fortunately, His mercy toward His people is unlimited. When we began to grasp the extent of His mercy toward us we see what true love is and how deeply God loves us. Although our sins deserve severe judgment, God has chosen to show love and mercy to all who seek Him.
original_verse_text: The Lord your God is the God of all gods and Lord of all lords. He is the Great God, mighty and awesome, who shows no partially and takes no bribes.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we praise You as the one true God, mighty and awesome in power and justice. Yet, in Your great mercy, You have chosen to show love and compassion to all who turn to You, even though we deserve judgment for our sins. We are humbled by the depth of Your love, as demonstrated through the sacrifice of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help us to walk in Your ways and reflect Your love to the world. Amen.
reflection: In saying that the Lord your God is God of all gods and Lord of lords, Moses was distinguishing the true God from all the local gods worshiped throughout the land. Then Moses went a step further, calling God “mighty and awesome.” He has such awesome power and justice that people cannot stand before Him without His mercy. Fortunately, His mercy toward His people is unlimited. When we begin to grasp the extent of His mercy toward us, we see what true love is and how deeply God loves us. Although our sins deserve severe judgment, God has chosen to show love and mercy to all who seek Him.
